class_notes: This course meets synchronously on Tuesdays and Thursdays. In this course we will examine health, illness, and health care institutions as social phenomena, in four parts that move from the macro-social to the micro-social, and across cultures. In Part I we will learn about population trends in health and the aging of our global society, as well as the social forces that playa determining role. In Part II we will examine and compare health care institutions in the US and severalindustrialized countries, with special attention to the Affordable Care Act, which is undergoing changes atpresent. In Part III we will study the social relationships and roles of health care providers and patients.Finally, in Part IV we take up issues of the experience of illness and the role that health plays in individual identity.
course_description: Social etiology and ecology of disease, sociological factors affecting treatment and rehabilitation, and the organization of medical care and medicine as a social institution.
